results.title: The Cherry blossom trail
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger and Grainger Television Australia
results.brief_description: Essentially a travel video, “The Cherry blossom trail” uses the revered time of beauty in Japan - Hanami (the brief period of time in which the cherry blossoms, known as sakura, flower before being driven away by the rain - as a compass for this tour of Japan. Beginning in Kyushu, host Greg Grainger and his guide/interpreter Ian visit a shinto shrine, observe the superstitions surrounding Japan’s national flower, visit a canola crop, hot sands and natural springs, countryside walkways, samurai village, origami cranes in the peace park, a traditional tea ceremony, sake and pottery production, geishas, sumo school, traditional villages and a seventeenth century castle, all set against the backdrop of exquisite flowers and gardens. The journey ends at Mount Fuji.

results.title: The Chelsea Flower Show (Captioned)
results.brief_description: It was in 1913 that the Royal Horticultural Society moved its Great Spring Show from the Temple Gardens to the Royal Chelsea Hospital. This commemorative video looks back over the last 75 golden years and illustrates this fascinating history with period photographs, film and music. Rated: G

results.title: Bruce McGuinness in Melbourne
results.brief_description: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. Activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).
results.description: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. It was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to historian and Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the period. Fellow activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).
description_for_label: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. It was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to historian and Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the period. Fellow activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).

results.title: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith, Cannes Film Festival
results.brief_description: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights in Australia released films on Black Australia to mixed success. Fred Schepisi’s controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) divided audiences and demonstrated how non-Indigenous storytellers could co-opt Indigenous stories to great detriment.
results.title_for_label: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith, Cannes Film Festival
results.description: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights in Australia released films on Black Australia to mixed success. While Fred Schepisi’s controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) divided audiences and demonstrated how non-Indigenous storytellers could co-opt Indigenous stories to great detriment, Phillip Noyce’s Backroads (1977), made in close consultation with Gary Foley, was groundbreaking for tackling racism and giving First Peoples a say in how they were portrayed.
description_for_label: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights in Australia released films on Black Australia to mixed success. While Fred Schepisi’s controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) divided audiences and demonstrated how non-Indigenous storytellers could co-opt Indigenous stories to great detriment, Phillip Noyce’s Backroads (1977), made in close consultation with Gary Foley, was groundbreaking for tackling racism and giving First Peoples a say in how they were portrayed.

results.title: The Challenge of survival: chemicals
results.creator_credit: Paul Gerber, Dick Young Productions and EPCOT Educational Media
results.brief_description: Shows how advances in agricultural research have increased our crop yields but have at the same time created a serious threat to our natural resources. Illustrates how our current use of chemicals has led to the poisoning of the environment and resistance developed amongst some pests. Examines alternative methods of pest management. Narrated by Michael Kane.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Gerber, Dick Young Productions and EPCOT Educational Media
